title: Use distributive property
text: Use distributive property to rewrite the expression $$\frac{8x^3+6x^2}{2x}=\frac{8x^3}{2x}+\frac{6x^2}{2x}$$
speech: Use distributive property to rewrite the expression  fraction, 8 x cubed, plus 6 x squared, over, 2 x,  is equal to fraction, 8 x cubed, over, 2 x,  plus fraction, 6 x squared, over, 2 x,
pacedSpeech: Use distributive property to rewrite the expression  this expression

title: Use distributive property
text: As a reminder, the distributive law states $$\left(a+b\right) c=a c+b c$$
speech: As a reminder, the distributive law states  parentheses a plus b,  times c is equal to, a c plus b c
pacedSpeech: As a reminder, the distributive law states    a plus b,  times c is equal to, a c plus b c

title: Use distributive property
text: in this case, we can see divided by $$2x$$ as multiply by $$\frac{1}{2x}$$, $$a=8x^3$$ , $$b=6x^2$$, $$c=\frac{1}{2x}$$
speech: in this case, we can see divided by  2 x  as multiply by , fraction, 1 over, 2 x,  ,  a is equal to, 8 x cubed,  ,  b is equal to, 6 x squared, ,  c is equal to, fraction, 1 over, 2 x,

as multiply by  , fraction, 1 over, 2 x,

,   b is equal to, 6 x squared,

title: Simplify each term in expression
text: As a reminder, the power rule states for any integer $$m$$, $$n$$ and real number a, $$\frac{a^m}{a^n}=a^{m-n}$$
speech: As a reminder, the power rule states for any integer  m ,  n  and real number a,  fraction, a to the m-th, over, a to the n-th,  is equal to, a raised to the m minus n power
pacedSpeech: As a reminder, the power rule states for any integer   m
and real number a,   fraction, a to the m-th, over, a to the n-th,  is equal to, a raised to the m minus n power

title: Combine the simplified terms
text: As our last step, we can put the simplified terms back to the $$\operatorname{expression}\left(\frac{8x^3}{2x}\right)+\frac{6x^2}{2x}$$

subHints.title: Combine the simplified terms
subHints.text: in the expression $$\frac{8x^3}{2x}+\frac{6x^2}{2x}$$, replace $$\frac{8x^3}{2x}$$ with $$4x^2$$, and $$\frac{\operatorname{replace}\left(6x^2\right)}{2x}$$ with $$3x$$ then we yield a new expression
